 Hy ! 
I'm having some problems to use the setInitialTime(ti) method of ReactorNet
class in 
python. It seems that the time 'ti' is not set to the reactors in the 
reaktornetwork, because when I call the 'step' or 'advance' methods, the
time begins 
at 0. 
 
What I'm doing is to write a program that restart a calceled simulation, so
I need 
to set the initial time of the reactors to a value not zero, and the
integrators 
should use this time as initial time. 
 
Here an example: 
============================================================= 
rossi@pcwap04:~/Rafael/Temp> python 
Python 2.2 (#1, Mar 26 2002, 15:46:04) 
[GCC 2.95.3 20010315 (SuSE)] on linux2 
>>> from Cantera import * 
>>> from Cantera.Reactor import * 
>>> gas = GRI30() 
>>> r = Reactor(gas) 
>>> r.time() 
0.0 
>>> rnet = ReactorNet([r]) 
>>> rnet.setInitialTime(1.0)          <- here should r.time() be 1.0 
>>> r.time()                     
0.0 
>>> rnet.step(1.1) 
 Initializing reactor network. 
Reactor 0: 55 variables. 
Number of equations: 55 
Maximum time step:   1.1             <- maximun time step should be 0.1  
3.7754849713707522e-05               <- time should be > 1.0 
>>> rnet.step(1.1) 
0.37758625198678891 
>>> r.time() 
0.37758625198678891 
=============================================================== 
The same with more then one reactor in network. 
 
If you could help me, I'd appreciate. 
Thank you ! 
Rafael Rossi
